SubTopics: Apply place-value strategies to solve problems.
Content: Mario picks a whole number from 2 to 6.
He multiplies the number by 10.
He adds 20 to the product.
Mario then completes one more step.
The result of Mario completing this last step is a 5 in the ones place.
Which step could be the last step Mario completes?

Key.Rationale: Starts with 7 and ends with a 5 in the tens place.
Correct.
Thinks an operation involving 5 would give the result.
Tries 1 as the first number without realizing this is not in the initial interval and saw that the result was 5.

SubTopics: Round two- and three-digit whole numbers to the nearest ten or hundred, respectively.
Content: David correctly rounded the number of stickers he has to 300.
Which could be the number of stickers David has?

Key.Rationale: Confuses tens and hundreds place values.
Looks at ones digit only.
Correct.
Looks at hundreds digit only.

SubTopics: Add two- and three-digit whole numbers (limit sums from 100 through 1,000) and/or subtract two- and three-digit numbers from three-digit whole numbers.
Solve two-step word problems using the four operations (expressions are not explicitly stated). Limit to problems with whole numbers and having whole-number answers.
Content: Pat wins 209 tickets at a school fair.
Adam wins 253 tickets at the school fair.
They combine their tickets to buy a prize that costs 395 tickets.
How many tickets do they have remaining?

Key.Rationale: Does not regroup the 1 when adding 209 and 253.
Correct.
Subtracts 2 from 5 and 6 from 9 when subtracting 395 from 462.
Does not regroup the 1 when adding 209 and 253 and subtracts the 2 from 5 and 5 from 9 when subtracting 395 from 452.

SubTopics: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10–90 (e.g., 9 × 80, 5 × 60) using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.
Add two- and three-digit whole numbers (limit sums from 100 through 1,000) and/or subtract two- and three-digit numbers from three-digit whole numbers.
Content: Frank took 3 piano lessons at school.
Each lesson was 90 minutes long.
He also took a guitar lesson that was 40 minutes long.
What was the total length of time, in minutes, of Frank's music lessons?

Key.Rationale: Adds 90 and 40.
Adds all three values.
Does not regroup when adding.
Correct.

SubTopics: Compare two fractions with the same denominator (limit denominators to 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8), using the symbols >, =, or <, and/or justify the conclusions.
Content: The table below lists the amounts of time, in hours, it takes three students to go to school each morning.
problems/PA19G3M/media/5a.jpg
Which statement correctly compares the amounts of time, in hours, it takes two of the students to go to school?

Key.Rationale: Uses the incorrect comparison symbol.
Correct.

C.Choice: 1/6 < 4/6 because the numerators are less than the denominators.

Key.Rationale: Compares a numerator to a denominator.

D.Choice: 4/6 = 3/6 because both fractions have the same denominator.

Key.Rationale: Compares denominators instead of numerators.

SubTopics: Interpret and/or describe products of whole numbers (up to and including 10 × 10).
Content: Harsha has 48 toy cars.
She puts the toy cars on shelves.
She puts the same number of toy cars on each shelf.
Which sentence about the toy cars could be true?

A.Choice: There are 6 shelves and 7 toy cars on each shelf.

Key.Rationale: Multiplies incorrectly.

B.Choice: There are 6 shelves and 8 toy cars on each shelf.

Key.Rationale: Correct.

C.Choice: There are 7 shelves and 7 toy cars on each shelf.

Key.Rationale: Multiplies incorrectly.

D.Choice: There are 7 shelves and 8 toy cars on each shelf.

Key.Rationale: Multiplies incorrectly.

SubTopics: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication (up to and including 10 × 10) or division (limit dividends through 50 and limit divisors and quotients through 10) equation relating three whole numbers.
Interpret and/or describe whole-number quotients of whole numbers (limit dividends through 50 and limit divisors and quotients through 10).
Content: Curt uses 42 pencils to make groups of pencils.
Each group has 7 pencils.
The equation 42 ÷ The [_]  = 7 describes this story.
Which sentence correctly explains what the [_] equals?

A.Choice: The [_] equals the 6 groups Curt made.

Key.Rationale: Correct.

B.Choice: The [_] equals the 6 pencils Curt has remaining.

Key.Rationale: Picks the right number but does not know what it represents.

C.Choice: The [_] equals the 7 groups Curt made.

Key.Rationale: Picks another interpretation for the number 7.

D.Choice: The [_] equals the 7 pencils Curt has remaining.

Key.Rationale: Picks a correct interpretation of 7 in the problem but doesn't realize that 7 does not go in the box.

SubTopics: Interpret and/or model division as a multiplication equation with an unknown factor.
Content: An equation is shown below.
Which number sentence shows another way to find the value of the unknown number?

Key.Rationale: Correct.
Knows that the problem could be solved with multiplication but confuses the factors.
Knows that the problem could be solved with division but confuses the quotient and dividend.
Knows that the problem could be solved with division but confuses the divisor and dividend.

SubTopics: Use operations, patterns, and estimation strategies to solve problems (may include word problems).
Content: Bre puts 22 chocolate chip cookies onto a plate for her friends.
She puts 18 oatmeal cookies onto another plate.
Her friends eat 8 cookies.
Which estimate is closest to the number of cookies Bre still has?

Key.Rationale: Rounds correctly but then subtracts 20 from 20 and rounds 8 cookies to 10.
Correct.
Rounds 22 to 30 and then finds 30 + 20 – 10.
Accurately rounds all the numbers but then adds them together.

SubTopics: Represent two-step word problems using equations with a symbol standing for the unknown quantity. Limit to problems with whole numbers and having whole-number answers.
Solve one- and two-step problems using information to interpret data presented in scaled pictographs and scaled bar graphs (scales limited to 1, 2, 5, and 10).
Content: The graph below shows the number of each animal in a pet store.
problems/PA19G3M/media/10a.jpg
Maya is feeding the cats and dogs at the pet store.
She already gave food to 4 of the cats and none of the dogs.
Which number sentence can be used to find the total number of cats and dogs ([_]) Maya still needs to feed?

Key.Rationale: Correct.
Adds the cats and dogs but does not subtract those fed.
Uses dogs and birds (two tallest bars) as the total to be fed.
Uses all animals as the total.

SubTopics: Create or match a story to a given combination of symbols (+, –, ×, ÷, <, >, and =) and numbers.
Content: A family bought 8 gallons of orange juice this year.
The family also bought 1 gallon of apple juice this year.
The price of each gallon of juice was $4.00.
Which expression correctly shows how to find the total price of the juice the family bought this year?

Key.Rationale: Correct.
Adds all the numbers together.
Subtracts 4 instead of adding 4.
Multiplies all the numbers.

SubTopics: Analyze characteristics of polygons.
Content: Some shapes are shown below.
problems/PA19G3M/media/12a.jpg
Which statement about the shapes is most likely true?

Key.Rationale: Confuses the terms pentagon and polygon.

B.Choice: Each shape has an even number of sides.

Key.Rationale: Overlooks that the pentagon has an odd number of sides.

C.Choice: In each shape, every angle is equal in size.

Key.Rationale: Sees that each shape has at least one pair of equal-sized angles.

D.Choice: In each shape, every side is equal in length.

Key.Rationale: Correct.

SubTopics: Recognize rhombi, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals and/or draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
Content: Which shape is not a quadrilateral?

Key.Rationale: Correct.
Picks a shape that meets the criteria for a quadrilateral.
Picks a shape that meets the criteria for a quadrilateral.
Picks a shape that meets the criteria for a quadrilateral.

SubTopics: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
Content: Steve shaded a fraction of a shape's area as shown below.
problems/PA19G3M/media/14a.jpg
Which shape has the same fraction of its area shaded as the shape Steve shaded?

Key.Rationale: Sees that the same actual area was shaded.
Sees that the same size rectangle was used.
Sees that the circle is also divided vertically into 3 parts.
Correct.

SubTopics: Calculate elapsed time to the minute in a given situation (total elapsed time limited to 60 minutes or less).
Content: When Edwin left his home, he glanced at the clock.
He saw the minute hand pointing at the 9.
Edwin returned home less than one hour later.
When he walked in, he saw the minute hand pointing at the 6.
How many minutes was Edwin gone?

Key.Rationale: Subtracts 6 from 9 (the numbers the minute hand was pointing to).
Considers the hours between the numbers the minute hand was pointing to (from 9 to 12 is 3 and from 12 to 6 is 6, for a total of 9).
Switches the start and finish.
Correct.

SubTopics: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate units — whole numbers, halves, or quarters.
Content: Sabrina measured the lengths of all the paper clips shown below.
problems/PA19G3M/media/16a.jpg
Use your ruler to measure the lengths, in inches, of the paper clips.
Which line plot shows the lengths, in inches, of all the paper clips?

Key.Rationale: Places the lengths for 1 1/4 inches at 1 inch.
Correct.
Places all the measures at 1/4 inch less than the actual lengths.
Identifies only one instance of each measure.

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas, and exhibiting rectangles with the same area and different perimeters. Use the same units throughout the problem.
Content: In which pair do the figures have the same perimeter?

Key.Rationale: Confuses area and perimeter.
Chooses the two figures that are rectangles.
Splits the second figure into a square and a rectangle, finds the perimeters of each, and adds to get 8 + 6 = 14.
Correct.

SubTopics: Find the areas of plane figures.
Content: Miss Drake and Mr. Lee each have gardens.
Pictures of their gardens are shown below.
problems/PA19G3M/media/18a.jpg
problems/PA19G3M/media/18b.jpg
What is the area, in square meters, of Miss Drake's garden?
The shaded part of Mr. Lee's garden shows where he plants corn.
In what fraction of his garden does Mr. Lee plant corn?
Mr. Tillman has a rectangular-shaped garden with an area of 24 square meters.
What could be the side lengths, in meters, of Mr. Tillman's garden?
Length 1 (meters): :FR-1:
Length 2 (meters): :FR-2:
Explain why there can be more than one possible answer for Part C.
